channel.title: Bloomberg Markets

item.title: US Futures Slide as Trump Considers Iran Strikes: Markets Wrap
item.description: US equity futures dropped on Friday as President Donald Trump weighs whether to back Israel militarily in its conflict with Iran.
item.dc:creator: Richard Henderson

media:content.media:description: Traders work on the floor of the American Stock Exchange (AMEX) at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Wednesday, June 18, 2025. Federal Reserve officials left interest rates unchanged and continued to pencil in two rate cuts in 2025, saying uncertainty over the economic outlook was still high but had diminished.

item.title: JD.com Billionaire’s Viral Stunt Reignites China’s Food-Delivery Feud
item.description: One unusually warm evening in April, Richard Liu revved his scooter through Beijing’s traffic-snarled streets alongside other delivery workers, and then personally handed food orders to surprised customers. Later that night, over spicy hotpot and ice-cold beer, the JD.com Inc. founder welcomed a pair of riders from two rival delivery firms to his company.
item.dc:creator: Luz Ding, Zheping Huang, Claire Che

media:content.media:description: Richard Liu Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: Rural Bank Plans Return to Japan Bonds After Winning on Nvidia
item.description: A Japanese regional bank that has stood out among its peers for making money on assets ranging from US Treasuries to Nvidia Corp. is now looking closer to home for investments.
item.dc:creator: Taiga Uranaka

media:content.media:description: The Iyogin Holdings headquarters building in Matsuyama. Photographer: Taiga Uranaka/Bloomberg

item.title: Japan’s Stocks Still Under Shadow of BOJ Unwinding Bond Holdings
item.description: The Bank of Japan is fine-tuning its pullback from the bond market but this mustn’t obscure the fact that quantitative tightening is well underway and likely to cause instability in some stocks.
item.dc:creator: Hideyuki Sano

media:content.media:description: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Tuesday, June 17, 2025. The BOJ left its benchmark rate unchanged and unveiled a plan to slow its withdrawal from the bond market from next year in a sign of caution following heightened market volatility.

item.title: Canada Moves to Protect Steel and Aluminum Firms, Considers Higher Tariffs
item.description: Canada has opened the door to increasing its tariffs on US steel and aluminum next month if trade talks with the Trump administration stall.
item.dc:creator: Randy Thanthong-Knight, Brian Platt

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney, Canada's incoming prime minister, speaks at an ArcelorMittal Dofasco steel facility in Hamilton, Ontario, Canada, on Wednesday, March 12, 2025. Canada will keep its trade retaliation in place until the US lifts its own tariffs and commits to free trade, said Carney, who will succeed Justin Trudeau as Canada’s prime minister within days.

item.title: Australian Funds Cut US Treasury Holdings on Trump Policy Risks
item.description: A number of Australia’s biggest investors say they are cutting their holdings of US Treasuries, citing concern over President Donald Trump’s tariff and tax plans.
item.dc:creator: Richard Henderson, Amy Bainbridge

media:content.media:description: The US Treasury building in Washington, DC, US, on Tuesday, June 17, 2025. The US Treasury has $144 billion of extraordinary measures left, in addition to its cash pile, to help keep paying the government's bills, the department said, citing data as of June 11.

item.title: US Futures Drop as Trump Weighs Strikes on Iran: Markets Wrap
item.description: Oil trimmed earlier gains and equity futures remained lower after White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said President Trump will decide within two weeks whether to back Israel militarily in its conflict with Iran. The remarks offered some short-term clarity but did little to resolve broader uncertainty around potential US involvement and the risk of renewed energy-driven inflation.
item.dc:creator: Andre Janse Van Vuuren, Sagarika Jaisinghani

media:content.media:description: An electronic ticker displays figures for the Nikkei 225 Stock Average, top, and the Hang Seng Index on a footbridge in Pudong's Lujiazui Financial District in Shanghai, China, on Thursday, April 3, 2025. The US has hit China with the biggest-ever tariff hike on almost all Chinese products, bringing total levies to at least 54%, a move that could decimate Chinese shipments to the world’s largest economy.

item.title: Gold Holds as Traders Weigh Inflation Warning, Middle East Risks
item.description: Gold traded little changed as investors weighed rising geopolitical risks in the Middle East against an inflation warning from the Federal Reserve that raises the possibility of fewer US rate cuts.
item.dc:creator: Yihui Xie

item.title: First Quantum Takes Small Steps in Long Road to Panama Mine Restart
item.description: First Quantum Minerals Ltd. is receiving some encouraging signs for its shuttered mine in Panama, though the nation’s president warned there’s a long way to go before reaching a deal to restart.
item.dc:creator: James Attwood, Michael D McDonald

item.title: Oil Steadies as Trump Gives Two Weeks for Iran Strike Decision
item.description: Oil edged higher, paring earlier gains, after the White House said President Donald Trump would decide within two weeks whether to strike Iran, reducing speculation that the US would plunge into the conflict imminently.
item.dc:creator: Robert Tuttle, Alex Longley

item.title: EU’s Dombrovskis Says ‘Making Progress’ in Trade Talks With US
item.description: The European Union is continuing intensive trade talks with the US ahead of a July 9 tariff deadline set by President Donald Trump and is “making progress,” according to EU Economy Commissioner Valdis Dombrovskis.
item.dc:creator: Kamil Kowalcze, Michal Kubala

media:content.media:description: Valdis Dombrovskis, economy commissioner for the European Union (EU), during a news conference following a Eurogroup meeting in Luxembourg, on Thursday, June 19, 2025. The Eurogroup is about to kick off its search for a new president, with Paschal Donohoeseen on track to win a third term, a feat that would make the Irishman the second-longest-serving chair of the euro zones finance-chief meetings.

item.title: Irish Tycoon Coulson Nears Deal to Cede Ardagh to Creditors
item.description: Paul Coulson is nearing an agreement to hand creditors full control of Ardagh Group SA, the company he transformed into a global packaging giant.
item.dc:creator: Luca Casiraghi, Jill R Shah, Giulia Morpurgo

media:content.media:description: Ardagh Group Chairman Paul Coulson, left, is applauded as he rings a ceremonial bell to mark the IPO of his company, on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, Wednesday, March 15, 2017. (AP Photo/Richard Drew)

item.title: Canada Slashes Forecast for Making Housing More Affordable
item.description: Doubling the pace of homebuilding in Canada will only bring affordability back to levels seen right before the Covid-19 pandemic, according to a new government report that lowers expectations for the impact of construction on housing costs.
item.dc:creator: Ari Altstedter

media:content.media:description: A residential building under construction in Toronto.

item.title: Ex-Janus Henderson Analyst Found Guilty of Insider Trading
item.description: A former Janus Henderson Group Plc analyst and his sister were found guilty of running an insider trading ring that made close to £1 million ($1.3 million) from a London flat while they worked from home during the coronavirus lockdowns.
item.dc:creator: Lucca De Paoli, Upmanyu Trivedi

media:content.media:description: Redinel Korfuzi, a former analyst at Janus Henderson Group Plc, left, and his sister, Oerta Korfuzi, arrive at Southwark Crown Court in London, UK, on Wednesday, Feb. 19, 2025. Redinel Korfuzi is facing charges of conspiracy to insider trade and handling criminal property along with his sister, Oerta Korfuzi, his personal trainer Rogerio De Aquino and another at a 16 week London trial that started Thursday.

item.title: Diesel Passes $105 a Barrel on Mideast Worry and Key Spreads Rip
item.description: Diesel soared for a fifth day — topping the equivalent of $105 a barrel in Europe — with spreads that traders view as measures of market strength spiraling higher.
item.dc:creator: Jack Wittels, Alex Longley

media:content.media:description: HOUSTON, TEXAS - JUNE 18: In an aerial view, the LyondellBasell Houston refinery is seen at sunset on June 18, 2025 in Houston, Texas. Oil prices have spiked over concerns that the Israel and Iran war could lead into a broader conflict involving the United States. Israel, in its largest attack to date against Iran, has targeted several gas and oil depots including striking Tehran’s main gas depot and its central oil refinery according to a report from Iran’s oil ministry. (Photo by Brandon Bell/Getty Images)

item.title: Egypt Resumes Gas Imports From Israel Following Six-Day Halt
item.description: Egypt started to receive small quantities of natural gas from Israel, ending a six-day halt in supplies, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Salma El Wardany, Galit Altstein

media:content.media:description: The Leviathan natural gas field in the Mediterranean Sea.

item.title: American, United Pause Middle East Flights on Rising Tension
item.description: American Airlines Group Inc. suspended daily flights from the US to the capital of Qatar, while United Airlines Holdings Inc. paused service to Dubai because of military actions and heightened tensions in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Mary Schlangenstein, Leen Al-Rashdan

media:content.media:description: American Airlines and United Airlines airplanes at the Terminal A at Newark Liberty International Airport (EWR) in Newark, New Jersey, US, on Thursday, Jan. 12, 2023. The new terminal will see an estimated 14 million passengers annually with 33 common-use gates servicing Air Canada, American Airlines, JetBlue and United Airlines, according to the authority.

item.title: Campari’s Family Owner to Acquire Stake in PE Firm Bluegem
item.description: The controlling shareholder of distiller Davide-Campari Milano NV has agreed to acquire a minority stake in consumer-focused private equity firm Bluegem Capital Partners.
item.dc:creator: Pamela Barbaglia

media:content.media:description: Lagfin owns an about 52% stake in Campari, one of the world’s largest distillers.

item.title: European Stocks Slide for a Third Day on Geopolitical Worries
item.description: European stocks fell for a third straight session on concerns around escalating geopolitical tensions in the Middle East as well as worries about stickier US inflation.
item.dc:creator: Sagarika Jaisinghani

item.title: Burnley FC Owner Seeks £150 Million for Multi-Club Strategy
item.description: Sports investment firm ALK Capital is looking to raise around £150 million ($200 million) for its multi-club strategy, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: David Hellier, Giles Turner

media:content.media:description: BURNLEY, ENGLAND - APRIL 21: The players of Burnley celebrate promotion to the Premier League following the Sky Bet Championship match between Burnley FC and Sheffield United FC at Turf Moor on April 21, 2025 in Burnley, England. (Photo by Alex Livesey/Getty Images)

item.title: IMF Chief Says Now Is Great Time to Boost Global Role of Euro
item.description: International Monetary Fund Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva sees a chance to strengthen the euro’s wider role.
item.dc:creator: Kamil Kowalcze, Michal Kubala

media:content.media:description: Kristalina Georgieva, managing director of the International Monetary Fund (IMF), at a news conference during the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank Spring meetings at the IMF headquarters in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, April 25, 2025. The International Monetary Fund sharply lowered its forecasts for world growth for this year and next, warning the outlook could deteriorate further as US President Donald Trump's tariffs spark a global trade war.

item.title: Bank of Montreal Buys Burgundy Asset to Boost Wealth Unit
item.description: Bank of Montreal is buying Burgundy Asset Management Ltd., boosting its wealth management business by adding an established Canadian firm that manages money for affluent individuals, pensions and foundations.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Shin

media:content.media:description: A Bank of Montreal (BMO) building in the financial district of Toronto, Ontario, Canada, on Thursday, April 24, 2025. As President Donald Trump's trade war continues, Canadian equities are poised to outperform their US counterparts, portfolio managers argue.

item.title: SARB Warns Trade, War Shocks Threaten South African Banks
item.description: Growing geopolitical upheaval and global policy uncertainty are among the biggest risks facing South Africa’s financial industry, the central bank said.
item.dc:creator: Adelaide Changole, Zinhle Xaba

media:content.media:description: Johannesburg

item.title: Nigerian Lenders Unveil Asset Remedy Plans After Regulator Order
item.description: Top Nigerian banks will make provisions for non-performing loans and cut exposure to certain clients that are above regulatory thresholds, responding to a central bank directive that raised questions and hurt their shares.
item.dc:creator: Emele Onu

media:content.media:description: A general view of the Central bank of Nigeria headquarters in the central business district in Abuja, on May 21, 2025. (Photo by OLYMPIA DE MAISMONT / AFP) (Photo by OLYMPIA DE MAISMONT/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Spain Heat Wave Tests Power Grid’s Post-Blackout Pivot to Gas
item.description: Increasing power demand to cool homes in Spain is putting pressure on energy prices after the country’s grid boosted its reliance on gas generation in the wake of a massive blackout.
item.dc:creator: Eamon Farhat

media:content.media:description: Extreme heat in Madrid, June 16.

item.title: Contested UK Oil Fields Get New Guidance for Environment Permits
item.description: Two controversial oil and gas fields in the UK — led by Equinor ASA and Shell Plc — will now have the opportunity to re-apply for environmental permits after the government published a guidance on how it will asses the climate impact of fossil fuel projects.
item.dc:creator: Elena Mazneva

item.title: Summers Sees Trump Naming ‘Respected’ Replacement for Powell
item.description: Former Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers said he expects Donald Trump to name a mainstream candidate to replace Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell, despite the president’s bashing of the US central bank leader for failing to cut interest rates this year.
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey

media:content.media:description: Larry Summers, president emeritus and professor at Harvard University, during a Bloomberg Television interview at the Allen & Co. Media and Technology Conference in Sun Valley, Idaho, US, on Thursday, July 13, 2023. The summit is typically a hotbed for etching out mergers over handshakes, but could take on a much different tone this year against the backdrop of lackluster deal volume, inflation and higher interest rates.

item.title: Windfall Levy Accounted for One Third of BP’s 2024 UK Tax Bill
item.description: BP Plc paid £1.25 billion ($1.6 billion) in taxes to the UK government in 2024, with about a third of the payments a result of the country’s windfall charge.
item.dc:creator: Mitchell Ferman

media:content.media:description: A company logo sits at a BP Plc petrol and refueling station in London, U.K., on Tuesday, Aug. 4, 2020. BP Plc cut its dividend for the first time in a decade, removing a cornerstone of its investment case after the coronavirus pandemic upended almost every aspect of its business.

item.title: EDF May Curb French Nuclear Output From June 25 Due to Heat Wave
item.description: Electricite de France SA said a heat wave that’s spreading across the country may force it to curb nuclear output from June 25 due to the rising temperature of the Rhone river that’s used for cooling some of its reactors.
item.dc:creator: Francois De Beaupuy

media:content.media:description: Steam rises from the cooling towers of the Bugey nuclear power plant in Saint-Vulbas, France.

item.title: Non-Doms Trying to Sell London Homes, But No One Wants Them
item.description: The number of London homes for sale at £5 million ($6.8 million) or more rose to the highest on record last month, as the nation contends with the departure of wealthy foreigners looking to escape tax hikes. (Source: Bloomberg)
